content.subtitle: Understanding error and warning messages from the Dart analyzer

paragraphs.name: f789
paragraphs.text: Dart diagnostic messages

paragraphs.name: e5ad
paragraphs.text: Understanding error and warning messages from the Dart analyzer

paragraphs.name: 3a26
paragraphs.text: Have you ever seen an error message and wondered what it means and what you should do about it? There might be more information available to help you answer those questions than you realize.

paragraphs.name: 155d
paragraphs.text: Let’s take a fairly common example. There’s a problem in the following code:

metadata.alt: A simple class with a red squiggly line under the “length” in `values.length`

paragraphs.name: f075
paragraphs.text: In IntelliJ IDEA, the message is visible in the Dart Analysis view:

metadata.alt: IntelliJ IDEA screenshot with error message: The property `length` can’t be unconditionally accessed because the receiver can be `null`.

paragraphs.name: 174e
paragraphs.text: In Visual Studio Code, the problem message appears in the Problems panel:

metadata.alt: Visual Studio Code with the same error message as in the IntelliJ IDEA screenshot

paragraphs.name: 9ee3
paragraphs.text: It seems odd that there’s a problem because we just checked that values isn’t nullon the line above.

paragraphs.name: 6eff
paragraphs.text: The message tells us what’s wrong, but it doesn’t really help us understand why the check wasn’t sufficient or how to respond to the error. That extra information is actually available; it just might not be obvious how to find it. The rest of this article shows you how to find the location of this extra information in the output of IntelliJ IDEA, Visual Studio Code, and the dart analyze command-line tool.

paragraphs.name: d0d1
paragraphs.text: IntelliJ IDEA

paragraphs.name: b9c9
paragraphs.text: If you hover over the highlighted text you can get more information:

metadata.alt: Screenshot of IntelliJ IDEA, with the contents described in the following text

paragraphs.name: c6b8
paragraphs.text: The hover includes the message we saw above (which we call the problem message), but it also includes other useful information:

paragraphs.name: b13b
paragraphs.text: A link to external documentation about the diagnostic

paragraphs.name: 5eb0
paragraphs.text: A context message that explains why the null comparison wasn’t sufficient to promote the type of the property to be non-nullable
A correction message that describes some of the things you can do to correct the code

paragraphs.name: 3e9e
paragraphs.text: The context message includes the URL of additional documentation related to type promotion and tells you the line and file on which the field is defined. Unfortunately you can’t navigate to the context location from the hover, but you can from the Dart Analysis view.

paragraphs.name: 43dd
paragraphs.text: Although the Dart Analysis view displays only the problem message, double-clicking the message navigates you to the text with the red squiggly underline where the problem is being reported. For other useful features, bring up the context menu:

metadata.alt: A screenshot of the context menu for the error message

paragraphs.text: With the context menu, you can navigate to either the location where the diagnostic was reported (using Jump to Source, which works just like double-clicking the problem message) or to the declaration of values (using the menu item labeled by the context message). Selecting Open Documentation opens the external documentation about the diagnostic.

paragraphs.name: 5eaf
paragraphs.text: Visual Studio Code

paragraphs.name: 9fa6
paragraphs.text: In Visual Studio Code there are two ways to see the extra information. The first is to expand the entry in the Problems panel:

metadata.alt: Screenshot of VS Code’s Problems panel

paragraphs.name: 10da
paragraphs.text: The first line is the message we saw before (which we call the problem message). Double-clicking either the first or second line navigates you to the text with the red squiggly underline where the problem is.

paragraphs.name: 8a51
paragraphs.text: The second line is a correction message that describes some of the things you can do to correct the code. It also contains a link, labeled by the ID of the diagnostic, that opens external documentation about the diagnostic.

paragraphs.name: d3cd
paragraphs.text: The third line is a context message that explains why the null comparison wasn’t sufficient to promote the type to be non-nullable. Double-clicking the context message navigates you to the declaration of values. The context message includes the URL of additional documentation related to type promotion.

paragraphs.name: ee6d
paragraphs.text: You can also see this information by hovering over the highlighted text, which causes hover text to be opened:

metadata.alt: Screenshot of VS Code hover text

paragraphs.name: 52a7
paragraphs.text: The hover text contains the same information as the Problems panel. It contains a link to take you to the external documentation and another link to navigate to the declaration of values.

paragraphs.name: 5c73
paragraphs.text: dart analyze

paragraphs.name: 8fad
paragraphs.text: The command-line analyzer dart analyze can display the same information as the IDEs, but you need to use the--verboseflag to see all of it.

metadata.alt: Screenshot of output from `dart analyze --verbose demo.dart`

paragraphs.name: 068b
paragraphs.text: Summary

paragraphs.name: e950
paragraphs.text: I hope this article helps you more easily find the information you need to understand the analyzer’s diagnostics.

paragraphs.name: 25ad
paragraphs.text: If you find diagnostics that are still hard to understand — because the message isn’t clear, it needs a context message to help you find other related code locations, or the documentation isn’t complete enough — please let us know by creating a dart-lang/sdk issue. We’re always interested in improving the tools.
